title.narrative: ICSIAPL

description.narrative:
Agriculture contributes 26% to Kenya’s Gross Domestic Product and especially in Arid and Semi-Arid Lands (ASALs), livestock is the main contributor to the agricultural sector. About 90% of family income and employment in these areas comes from livestock, but the sector faces multiple challenges: the land is often overgrazed and overstocked, human population growth causes competition for land use (settlements), soil fertility is declining, and climate change, including prolonged droughts and flooding, pose threats to both the vulnerable population and the herds. Farmers use extensive farming systems and the inadequate supply of certified forage seeds and vegetative planting materials and low commercialization of forage production leaves much potential for improvement.
The main constraints the Action will address are:
1) low adoption and upscaling of innovative and climate smart technologies;
2) lack of knowledge on and application of sustainable market-based models for fodder production that fit prevailing local conditions and landscapes
3) weakly developed capacities of county governments and other stakeholders and weak coordination on resource planning and management at landscape level;
4) weak policy environment and implementation of policies at the county level; and
5) limited involvement and investment of the private sector.
The sited factors depict the prevailing situation in the three counties of Narok, Kajiado and Taita Taveta in varying proportions as per context.
ICSIAPL is a partnership initiative of SNV Kenya and the Kenya Agricultural and Livestock Research Organization (KALRO) implemented with funding support from the European Union’s (EU) DeSIRA Initiative (Development Smart Innovation through Research in Agriculture) on the one hand; and The Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (EKN) on the other hand. Funding is through the delegated cooperation mechanism whereby EU entrusts funds to entities from EU Member states, the Directorate General for Development Cooperation (DGIS) in this case. It also involves, collaboration with the three county governments within the selected project sites; Narok, Kajiado and Taita Taveta.

At the heart of the initiative is the application of research towards building more resilient and market-based solutions for improved forage production and livestock husbandry through climate smart innovations and sustainable landscape management. The project aims to stimulate business models around grazing, and forage production and sales in order to provide opportunities for women and youth enterprise development, as well as opportunities for large scale commercial production. ICSIAPL aims to support counties to build on the commercialisation of climate-smart innovations and to develop sustainable landscape management
Integrated & Climate Smart Innovations for Agro-Pastoralist Economies and Landscapes in Kenya’s ASALs

Targeted agro-pastoralists, youth and women in the regions of intervention, private sector, local enterprises (MSMEs), ranches, conservancies and cooperatives, national and county government partners.

participating-org.narrative: Kenya Agriculture and Livestock Research Organisation

mailing-address.narrative: Ngong Lane Off Ngong Road, Nairobi, The Netherlands

title.narrative: The number of private sector actors applying climate-resilient and environmentally sustainable production practices due to the action
County governments supported to develop and implement drought resilient feed and fodder strategy and policies which enable business opportunities for women and youth.
The number of county governments developing a feed and fodder strategy
The number of feed and fodder strategies developed which include creating business opportunities for women & youth with a specific focus on inclusiveness (gender and youth);
The number of inclusive county innovation platforms on integrated landscape management strategies supportive of livestock value chain actors
Counties coordinate on harmonised grazing arrangements based on feed inventories and common strategies for herd mobility
The number of cross-county agreements on grazing and herd mobility, harmonised cess duties and grazing payment arrangements
The number of feed resource inventories and analyses of grazing/landscape plans developed

Improved capacity of county technical staff and county executive members (Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of Environment) to develop drought resilient livestock sector policies which are favourable for private sector participation/engagement, and inclusive for women and youth
Number of counties that have been able to influence national bodies to facilitate access to necessary inputs for value chain actors

The number of counties that have drafted county bills to adapt national policies (e.g. Agriculture Sector Transformation and Growth Strategy, the National Livestock Policy and the National Animal Feed and Forage Inventory and Strategy) and have included these in the next phase of their CIDP

Improved capacity of county technical staff and county executive members (Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of Environment) to develop drought resilient livestock sector policies which are favourable for private sector participation/engagement, and inclusive for women and youth
